p.text: Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 falls under Schedule 7 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 which was assented to on 1 June 2005. It commenced on 15 August 2005. *

row.entry: Dust Diseases Tribunal Amendment (Claims Resolution) Act 2005 No 22
Uniform Civil Procedure Rules (Amendment No 1) 2005 No 395
Uniform Civil Procedure Rules (Amendment No 2) 2005 No 396
Uniform Civil Procedure Rules (Amendment No 3) 2005 No 625
Uniform Civil Procedure Rules (Amendment No 4) 2005 No 717
r 1–3: 7 December 2007; Sch 1: 7 December 2007; Sch 3: 1 January 2008; Sch 4[1] and [3]: 1 January 2008; Sch 2 and Sch 4[2]: 6 July 2009 (r 2)
Health Practitioner Regulation Amendment Act 2010 No 34
Courts and Crimes Legislation Further Amendment Act 2010 No 135

p.text: These rules were formerly contained in Schedule 7 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005. The continued effect of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules is unaffected by the repeal of Schedule 7 by Sch 5 cl 5.3[4] of the Civil Procedure Act 2005. See s 30 of the Interpretation Act 1987.

row.entry: These rules contain preliminary definitional provisions. Rule 1.4 preserves the right to commence proceedings for discovery.
These rules detail the application of the UCPR and the CPA to particular kinds of civil proceedings. They regulate the priority between the UCPR and the local rules of particular courts.

The rules provide the courts with power to determine disputed questions arising under the rules, including questions of privilege, and expressly permit inspection of disputed documents. The rules prescribe the powers of Associate Judges (SC) and the judicial registrar of the District Court.
These rules regulate the fixing, reckoning and variation of times for conduct provided for in the rules and in judgments and orders.

entry.emph: Division 3 — Fees and other amounts — Rules 1.14 –1.15

row.entry: This Division contains rules governing the fees payable under various provisions of the UCPR and under the Oaths Act 1900.

entry.emph: Division 4 — Assignment of Divisional business in the Supreme Court — Rules 1.16 –1.21

row.entry: This Division contains rules governing the distribution of business between the Common Law Division and the Equity Division of the Supreme Court. Rule 1.21 sets out the circumstances when the Supreme Court can order that proceedings be moved to the Court of Appeal.

entry.emph: Division 5 — Notices under s 78B of the Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth) – Rules 1.22 –1.25

row.entry: This Division sets out the procedures for filing and service where a party raises a constitutional matter and is required to serve Judiciary Act notices.

entry.emph: Division 6 — Procedure in particular circumstances — Rules 1.26–1.27

row.entry: Rule 1.26 applies the provisions of Sch 10 to matters arising under specified NSW and Commonwealth legislation. Rule 1.27 applies the provisions in Sch 11 to specified compensation lists in the District Court.
This Part applies to all courts in Sch 1 of the CPA: see r 1.5 and Sch 1. The Part also applies to the criminal proceedings in the Third Schedule to the Supreme Court Act: see SCR Pt 75 r 3 .

Most of the rules in Divs 1 and 3 are machinery provisions unique to the UCPR. The specific powers to inspect disputed documents are consistent with the general law position. The time provisions in Div 2 are substantially based on the former SCR Pts 1 and 2 and DCR Pt 3. Additional provisions relating to privilege, substantially derived from SCR Pt 36 r 13, are contained in the s 87 of the CPA. The provisions in Div 4 dealing with the distribution of business between Divisions of the Supreme Court are based on the former SCR Pt 12. The provisions in Div 5 dealing with notices under s 78B of Judiciary Act (Cth) are based on O 51 of the Federal Court Rules. The procedural provisions in Div 6 are based on former provisions in SCR Sch J and the DCA.

p.text: These rules are the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005.
Words and expressions that are defined in the Dictionary at the end of these rules have the meanings set out in the Dictionary.
Notes included in these rules do not form part of these rules.
In the notes, DCR means the District Court Rules 1973, LCR means the Local Courts (Civil Claims) Rules 1988 and SCR means the Supreme Court Rules 1970.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.3] r 1.3 References to barristers and solicitors

p.text: For the purposes of these rules:
a reference in these rules to a barrister is a reference to a legal practitioner who practises as a barrister, and
a reference in these rules to a solicitor is a reference to a legal practitioner who practises as a solicitor.
The rights of a person to practise as a barrister or to practise as a solicitor are regulated by the Legal Profession Act 2004.
[subr (1) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[1]–[2], effective 8 December 2006]
For the purposes of rule 33.9(9) , a reference to a solicitor for a party includes a reference to:
a solicitor acting as agent for the solicitor for a party, and
any other solicitor belonging to or employed by the same firm or organisation as the solicitor for a party or the solicitor acting as agent for the solicitor for a party.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 9 June 2006; am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 8 December 2006]
For the purposes of rule 33.9(10) :

a reference to a solicitor who removes a document or thing from the office of the registrar includes a reference to a solicitor who directs a person referred to in paragraph (b) to remove a document or thing from the office of the registrar, and
a reference to the personal custody of the solicitor includes a reference to the personal custody of:
any other solicitor belonging to or employed by to the same firm or organisation as that solicitor, or any other person employed by that firm or organisation, and
any other solicitor acting as agent for that solicitor, and
any other solicitor belonging to or employed by to the same firm or organisation as a solicitor acting as agent for that solicitor, or any other person employed by that firm or organisation, and
if the registrar has approved a firm or organisation to provide photocopying services in respect of documents, any employee of a firm or organisation so approved.
[subr (3) insrt Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 9 June 2006; am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 8 December 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.4] r 1.4 Saving as to discovery (cf SCR Part 1, rule 14)

leg:heading.title: Saving as to discovery (cf SCR Part 1, rule 14)

p.text: These rules do not affect the right of any person to commence proceedings for discovery.

level.toc-caption: [1.4.5] Discovery proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 21.1, 21.8, rr 5.1, 5.8.

There are specific provisions relating to discovery in rr 5.1 – 5.8 (preliminary discovery to obtain a prospective defendant’s identity or whereabouts) and rr 21.1 – 21.8 (discovery and inspection in substantive claims in existing proceedings). The saving provision in the present rule preserves the power of the Supreme Court to entertain separate proceedings for discovery.

level.toc-caption: [1.4.10] History of discovery proceedings

p.text: Discovery originated in the Chancery jurisdiction and was not available at common law. However, a party to a common law action could file a bill in equity for discovery. When this occurred, the common law action would be adjourned or stayed until the equity proceedings were determined: McLean v Burns Philp Trustee Co Pty Ltd (1985) 2 NSWLR 623; 9 ACLR 926 (which contains a brief history of the procedure); Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2004] NSWSC 695; BC200405120 at [107] ; Corrs Pavey Whiting & Byrne v Collector of Customs (Vic) (1987) 14 FCR 434 at 445–6; 13 ALD 254 ; Survival & Industrial Equipment (Newcastle) Pty Ltd v Owners of the Vessel “Alley Cat” (1992) 36 FCR 129 .

Eventually the common law courts were given a statutory power to order discovery: Evidence Act 1851 (UK) and Common Law Procedure Act 1854 (UK). There is a discussion of the ambit of the statutory power in several cases: see Roberts v Oppenheim (1884) 25 Ch D 724 at 733; Naismith v McGovern (1953) 90 CLR 336; [1953] ALR 846 ; Bustros v White (1876) 1 QBD 423 ; R v Associated Northern Collieries (1910) 11 CLR 738; 17 ALR 359 . The courts of common law in New South Wales were given the power to order discovery by s 102 of the Common Law Procedure Act 1899: see Smith’s Weekly Publishing Co Ltd v Sunday Times Newspaper (1923) 31 CLR 552 . The introduction of rules of court regulating discovery did not mark any significant changes in the principles that had been developed in Chancery. See generally Commonwealth v Miller (1910) 10 CLR 742; [1911] VLR 60 and McLean v Burns Philp Trustee Co Pty Ltd (1985) 2 NSWLR 623 at 643–6; 9 ACLR 926 (where Young J discusses the history of the bill of discovery in Equity and the court’s inherent power to make orders for discovery). But the introduction of the rule-based general procedure marked a corresponding decline in the use of separate proceedings in equity: Hooper v Kirella Pty Ltd (1999) 96 FCR 1 at 9; 167 ALR 358; [1999] FCA 1584; BC9907490 . Nevertheless, the power continued as an aspect of the court’s ability to secure the due administration of justice and ensure the efficacy of its proceedings: Heimann v Commonwealth (1935) 54 CLR 126 at 133; [1935] ALR 501 ; Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Lenah Game Meats Pty Ltd (2001) 208 CLR 199 at 243; 185 ALR 1; [2001] HCA 63; BC200107043 ; Ashworth Hospital Authority v MGN Ltd [2002] 4 All ER 193; [2002] 1 WLR 2033 . Rule 1.4 preserves the right of any person to commence proceedings for discovery.

level.toc-caption: [1.4.15] Requirements for discovery — arguable case

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.4.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 5.

Exercise of the additional power to order discovery depends upon (i), satisfaction that the claimant has an arguable cause of action or bona fide claim: Ashworth Hospital Authority v MGN Ltd [2002] 4 All ER 193; [2002] 1 WLR 2033 ; Glaxo Wellcome PLC v Minister of National Revenue (1998) 162 DLR (4th) 433; [1998] 4 FC 439 ; Norwich Pharmacal Co v Customs and Excise Cmrs [1974] AC 133; [1973] 2 All ER 943 ; and (ii) that discovery is reasonably necessary to allow the claim to be determined on its merits and result in an effective judgment. The first requirement has been flexibly applied to require only sufficient evidence of probable “wrongdoing”: Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2004] NSWSC 695; BC200405120 at [126] ; Ashworth Hospital Authority v MGN Ltd , above, at [57] — either by the discovery defendant or by a person with whom they have become relevantly “involved”: Norwich Pharmacal Co v Customs and Excise Cmrs , above (discovery against body who obtained control of goods and records pursuant to statutory obligations); British Steel Corp v Granada Television Ltd [1981] AC 1096; [1981] 1 All ER 417 (discovery against newspaper to whom stolen confidential documents had been provided). Consequently, orders for discovery have been made to enable an applicant to determine whether they had a cause of action: P v T Ltd [1997] 4 All ER 200; [1997] 1 WLR 1309 . They have also been made against third parties in aid of tracing remedies: Bankers Trust Co v Shapira [1980] 3 All ER 353; [1980] 1 WLR 1274 ; Arab Monetary Fund v Hashim (No 5) [1992] 2 All ER 911 ; in relation to both pre-judgment: A v C [1981] 2 WLR 629 and post-judgment Mareva orders: Mercantile Group (Europe) AG v Aiyela [1994] QB 366; [1994] 1 All ER 110 . In Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd , above, at [126], discovery was ordered to further a prospective costs application against third parties. Orders have also been made, especially in copyright or confidential information cases, for discovery for disclosure of the name of prospective defendants: see, for example, Computershare Ltd v Perpetual Registrars Ltd (2000) 1 VR 626; [2000] VSC 139; BC200002289 ; RCA Corp v Reddingtons Rare Records [1975] 1 All ER 38; [1974] 1 WLR 1445 ; Loose v Williamson [1978] 3 All ER 89; [1978] 1 WLR 639 ; British Steel Corp v Granada Television Ltd , above, (although in such cases an alternative preliminary discovery procedure now also exists under Pt 5 of the Rules. Typically these cases involve “tortious” wrongdoing, but views differ as to whether this defines, as distinct from illustrates, the scope of the power: National Education Advancement Programs (NEAP) Pty Ltd v Ashton (1995) 33 IPR 281; 128 FLR 334; BC9506806 (confined to tort claims); Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd, above.

level.toc-caption: [1.4.20] Requirements for discovery — reasonable necessity

p.text: The second requirement for the exercise of the additional power to order discovery is that of reasonable necessity. This requirement inevitably overlaps with the first requirement to the degree that it requires evidence of “wrongdoing”. But it adds an additional limitation which requires consideration of the objective necessity of the order having regard to matters such as alternative remedies available to an applicant, and the distinction between establishing a cause of action and satisfying a judgment. Discovery will not be ordered if the claimant has an alternative right to obtain the information, including by resort to freedom of information legislation: Corrs Pavey Whiting & Byrne v Collector of Customs (Vic) (1987) 14 FCR 434 at 446; 13 ALD 254 ; Glaxo Wellcome PLC v Minister of National Revenue (1998) 162 DLR (4th) 433 at 449; [1998] 4 FC 439 ; Re Application of Cojuangco (1986) 4 NSWLR 513 at 520 ; Ashworth Hospital Authority v MGN Ltd [2002] 4 All ER 193; [2002] 1 WLR 2033 at 57 . Nor is discovery available to determine the sufficiency of prospective defendant’s assets to meet any final judgment that might be obtained: GIO Insurance Ltd v Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd (1995) 8 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61-293 (bill of discovery is not available in insurance cases to require the insured to disclose details of other insurances); Beneficial Finance Corp Ltd v Price Waterhouse (1996) 68 SASR 19 at 35; 189 LSJS 364; BC9606539 — but see [5.2.20] .

level.toc-caption: [1.4.25] Joinder of parties for the purpose of discovery

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.4.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 5.2.

heading.title: Joinder of parties for the purpose of discovery

p.text: Ordinarily, no action lies to obtain discovery unless the party seeking discovery can assert a substantive independent right against the person from whom discovery is sought: Plummer v May (1750) 1 Ves sen 246; 27 ER 1121; Bray, Principles and Practice of Discovery, 1885, p 41; cf P v T Ltd [1997] 4 All ER 200; [1997] 1 WLR 1309 (discovery of defamatory complaints made to the defendant by an unidentified person). Accordingly, a party who has been joined merely for the purpose of obtaining discovery against it may be dismissed from the proceedings: Wilson v Church (1878) 9 Ch D 552 ; Burstall v Beyfus (1884) 26 Ch D 35 ; Gould v National Provincial Bank Ltd [1960] Ch 337; [1960] 1 All ER 544 . However, if there is a proper substantive claim against the party joined, it is immaterial that a motive for the joinder was to obtain discovery: Nicholls v McLeay [1971] 1 SASR 442. And, notwithstanding the general proposition that ordinarily there is no independent action for discovery, in an appropriate case an action will lie to obtain discovery of the name of a wrongdoer: British Steel Corp v Granada Television Ltd [1981] AC 1096; [1981] 1 All ER 417 ; see generally rr 5.2 and 5.3 of the Rules.
Subject to subrule (2), these rules apply to each court referred to in Column 1 of Schedule 1 in relation to civil proceedings of a kind referred to in Column 2 of that Schedule.

In respect of each court referred to in Column 1 of Schedule 1, civil proceedings of a kind referred to in Column 2 of that Schedule are excluded from the operation of each provision of these rules referred to in Column 4 of that Schedule in respect of those proceedings.
The exclusion of civil proceedings from any such provision is subject to such conditions, limitations or exceptions as are specified in Column 4 of Schedule 1 in relation to that provision.
[subr (3) insrt Amendment 31 of 2009 Sch 1[1], effective 1 February 2010]

Without limiting the operation of subrule (2), if any Part, Division or other provision of these rules provides that it applies to proceedings or other matters in a specified court or courts, the Part, Division or other provision does not apply to proceedings or other matters in any other court.
[subr (4) insrt Amendment 54 of 2012 r 3, effective 10 August 2012]

level.toc-caption: [1.5.5] Application of the UCPR in various courts

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 Sch 7.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 1.

heading.title: Application of the UCPR in various courts

p.text: In general terms, the CPA (including the UCPR rules which were enacted as Sch 7 of the Act) applies to all civil proceedings in the Supreme Court, District Court, Dust Diseases Tribunal, the Land and Environment Court, the Local Court and the Industrial Relations Commission (including the Commission in Court Session (the Industrial Court)). That general proposition is subject to the qualifications that: (i) some provisions of the rules expressly provide that they apply only in particular courts (see UCPR r 1.5(4)); and (ii) some rules are excluded (by reference to Column 4 of Sch 1 ) from applying to particular kinds of proceedings. There are no material exclusions from the rules in relation to proceedings in the Supreme Court. In relation to proceedings in other courts, in order to determine whether a particular rule applies it is necessary to have regard both to the terms of the rule and also to Sch 1. The position for each court (other than the Supreme Court) is summarised in the following notes.

level.toc-caption: [1.5.10] Exclusions relating to the District Court

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.5.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 11.1–11.12, rr 26.1–26.8, rr 40.1–40.4, rr 45.1–45.8.

heading.title: Exclusions relating to the District Court

p.text: Although there are no explicit exclusions relating to the District Court in Sch 1, the following UCPR in fact apply only to proceedings in the Supreme Court:
rr 11.1–11.12 (service of documents outside Australia)
rr 26.1–26.8 (appointment of receivers)
rr 40.1–40.4 (modes of enforcing judgments)
rr 45.1–45.8 (Supreme Court specialist lists)
rr 46.10–46.28 (Accounts and inquiries — Equity Division of Supreme Court)
rr 48.1–48.24 (Matters arising under Commonwealth intellectual property legislation)

level.toc-caption: [1.5.15] Exclusions relating to the DDT

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.5.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

Some of the UCPR only apply in the Supreme Court and District Court. In addition, Sch 1 excludes r 15.18 (interim payments) and Pts 21 and 22 (discovery and interrogatories) from proceedings in the Dust Diseases Tribunal. The combined result is that the following rules do not apply to proceedings in the Dust Diseases Tribunal:
rr 11.1–11.12 (service of documents outside Australia)
r 15.18 (interim payments)
rr 21.1–21.12 (discovery and notices to produce)
rr 22.1–22.6 (interrogatories)
rr 24.1–24.20 (taking evidence otherwise than at trial)

rr 25.1–25.9
(interim preservation)
rr 26.1–26.8 (appointment of receivers)
rr 40.1–40.8 (modes of enforcing judgments)
rr 45.1–45.14 (Specialist lists)
rr 46.10–46.28 (Accounts and inquiries — Equity Division of Supreme Court)
rr 48.1–48.24 (Matters arising under Commonwealth intellectual property legislation)

level.toc-caption: [1.5.17] Exclusions relating to the Land and Environment Court

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.5.17] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 11.

heading.title: Exclusions relating to the Land and Environment Court

p.text: The UCPR apply (subject to the priority of local rules: see CPA s 11 and UCPR Sch 2 ) to civil proceedings in the following classes of proceedings in the Land and Environment Court:
class 1 (environmental planning and protection appeals);
class 2 (local government and miscellaneous appeals and applications);
class 3 (land tenure, valuation, ratings and compensation matters);
class 4 (environmental planning and protection and development contract civil enforcement);
class 8 (proceedings arising under the Mining Act 1992 or the Petroleum (Onshore) Act 1991).
UCPR Sch 1 (column 4) specifically excludes the following rules from class 1, 2, or 3 proceedings:
rr 6.2–6.8 (originating process);
rr 6.12–6.17 (contents of statement of claim);
rr 20.25–20.32 (compromise);
r 42.1 (general rule that costs follow the event);
r 42.6 (amendment of pleadings etc without leave);
r 42.8 (dispute of fact subsequently proved of admitted);
r 42.9 (dispute of authenticity of documents subsequently proved or admitted);

rr 42.13–42.17 (offers of compromise) (exclude from all proceedings other than those in various specified sections of the Land and Environment Court Act 1979, the Local Government Act 1993 or the Fisheries Management Act 1994);
r 42.18 (offer to contribute);
r 42.19 (proceedings discontinued);
r 42.20 (dismissal of proceedings).
The following UCPR provisions do not apply or apply in a modified form to proceedings in class 1, 2 or 3 of the Land and Environment Court’s jurisdiction:
r 4.2(3A) (certification of prospects): see r 4.2(3B)
r 18.3(1)(a)(ii) and (b)(ii) (identification of persons in notices of motion): see r 18.3(1A) .

level.toc-caption: [1.5.18] Exclusions relating to the Industrial Court

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.5.18] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 Div 3, s 11.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 16, Pt 20, Pt 23, Pt 37, Pt 38, Pt 39, Pt 42, Pt 43, Pt 6, rr 23.1–23.5, rr 23.6–23.7, rr 42.12–42.17, Sch 1, Sch 2.
(NSW) Industrial Relations Act 1996 s 109.

heading.title: Exclusions relating to the Industrial Court

p.text: The UCPR applies (subject to the priority of local rules: see CPA s 11 and UCPR Sch 2 ) to civil proceedings in the Industrial Court. UCPR Sch 1 (column 4) specifically excludes the following rules:
Pt 6 (commencing proceedings an appearance)
Pt 16 (default judgment)
Pt 20 (resolution of proceedings without hearing) except Div 4 (compromise) — but Div 4 does not apply until after conciliation has been attempted under Industrial Relations Act 1996 s 109 )
Pt 23 , rr 23.1–23.5 (medical examinations); rr 23.6–23.7 (rehabilitation assessment)
Pt 37 (time to pay and payments by instalment)
Pt 38 (examination of judgment debtor)
Pt 39 (enforcement of judgments)
Pt 42 , rr 42.12–42.17 (arbitration rehearings under CPA Pt 5 Div 3 )
Pt 43 (interpleader proceedings)

level.toc-caption: [1.5.19] Exclusions relating to the Industrial Relations Commission (when constituted otherwise than as the Industrial Court)

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.5.19] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 11.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 16, Pt 17, Pt 20, Pt 21, Pt 22, Pt 23, Pt 31, Pt 32, Pt 34, Pt 37, Pt 38, Pt 39, Pt 42, Pt 43, Pt 46, Pt 5, Pt 6, rr 31.1, 31.11, 31.12, 31.16A, 31.2, 31.3, 31.4, Sch 1, Sch 2.

heading.title: Exclusions relating to the Industrial Relations Commission (when constituted otherwise than as the Industrial Court)

p.text: The UCPR applies (subject to the priority of local rules: see CPA s 11 and UCPR Sch 2 ) to civil proceedings in the Industrial Relations Commission (when constituted otherwise than as the Industrial Court). UCPR Sch 1 (column 4) specifically excludes the following rules:
Pt 5 (preliminary discovery and inspection)
Pt 6 (commencing proceedings an appearance)
Pt 16 (default judgment)
Pt 17 (admissions) except to the extent to which the Commission orders that the part is to apply
Pt 20 (resolution of proceedings without hearing)
Pt 21 (discovery, inspection and notice to produce documents) except to the extent to which the Commission orders that the part is to apply
Pt 22 (interrogatories)
Pt 23 (medical examinations and inspection of property)

Pt 31 (evidence) except for rr 31.1 (manner of giving evidence at trial), 31.2 (evidence of witnesses at other hearings), 31.3 (evidence by telephone, video link or other communication), 31.4 (court may direct party to furnish witness statement), 31.11 (production of court documents), 31.12 (proof of court documents), 31.16A (return of exhibits)
Pt 32 (evidence and procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 (Cth)
Pt 34 (notices to produce at hearing) except to the extent to which the Commission orders that the part is to apply
Pt 37 (time to pay and payments by instalment)
Pt 38 (examination of judgment debtor)
Pt 39 (enforcement of judgments)
Pt 42 (costs)
Pt 43 (interpleader proceedings)
Pt 46 (accounts and inquiries)

level.toc-caption: [1.5.20] Exclusions relating to the Local Court (General Division)

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.5.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: Exclusions relating to the Local Court (General Division)

p.text: The provisions which do not apply in the General Division of the Local Court can be summarised as follows:
rr 11.1–11.12 (service of documents outside Australia)
rr 24.1–24.20 (taking evidence otherwise than at trial)
rr 25.1–25.24 (interim preservation)
rr 26.1–26.8 (appointment of receivers)
rr 40.1–40.8 (modes of enforcing judgments)
rr 45.1–45.14 (Specialist lists)
rr 46.10–46.28 (Accounts and inquiries — Equity Division of Supreme Court)
rr 48.1–48.24 (Matters arising under Commonwealth intellectual property legislation)

level.toc-caption: [1.5.25] Exclusions relating to the Local Court (Small Claims Division)

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.5.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: Exclusions relating to the Local Court (Small Claims Division)

p.text: The provisions which do not apply in, or are explicitly excluded from, the Small Claims Division of the Local Court can be summarised as follows:
UCP Parts wholly excluded:
Pt 5 Preliminary discovery and inspection
Pt 11 Service outside Australia
Pt 13 Summary disposal
Pt 18 Motions (except in relation to applications under rr 23.8. 36.15, 36.16 and 43.6)
Pt 21 Discovery, inspection and notices to produce
Pt 22 Interrogatories
Pt 24 Taking evidence otherwise than at trial
Pt 25 Interim preservation
Pt 26 Receivers
Pt 27 Disposal of land
Pt 31 Evidence
Pt 32 Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994
Pt 33 Subpoenas
Pt 40 Additional measures for enforcement of judgments and orders of the Supreme Court and District Court
Pt 41 Funds in court
Pt 44 Transfer of proceedings
Pt 45 Specialist lists
Pt 48 Commonwealth intellectual property matters
Pt 49 Reviews and appeals within the court
Pt 50 Appeals to the court
Particular UCPR excluded:
r 6.13 Provision of address for filing documents
rr 7.4–7.18 and 7.23 Representation of parties
rr 14.4 and 14.5 Defence and Reply pleadings
rr 15.7 and 15.8 Exemplary and aggravated damages
rr 15.12 – 15.17 Particulars in personal injury claims
r 15.18 Interim payments
r 16.4 Default judgment for possession of land
rr 20.1–20.32 Mediation, Arbitration, Reference and Compromise
rr 23.1–23.7 Medical examination
rr 29.7 Procedure where party is absent
rr 29.9 Dismissal of proceedings on defendant’s application
rr 36.8 , 36.15–36.16 Judgment for possession of land and setting aside judgments
rr 39.21–39.28 Enforcement of writs against land and goods
rr 46.10–46.28 (Accounts and inquiries — Equity Division of Supreme Court)

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.6] r 1.6 Exclusion of provisions of Civil Procedure Act 2005

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of provisions of Civil Procedure Act 2005

p.text: In respect of each court referred to in Column 1 of Schedule 1 :

civil proceedings of a kind referred to in Column 2 of that Schedule are excluded from the operation of the provisions of Parts 3–9 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 referred to in Column 3 of that Schedule in respect of those proceedings, and
the following proceedings, to the extent to which they are civil proceedings, are excluded from all of Parts 3–9 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005:
proceedings under the Mental Health (Criminal Procedure) Act 1990,
proceedings under the Habitual Criminals Act 1957,
proceedings under the Bail Act 1978,
proceedings under the Crimes (Domestic and Personal Violence) Act 2007 ,
proceedings under Part 4 of the Victims Support and Rehabilitation Act 1996.
[r 1.6 am Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 6 March 2009]

level.toc-caption: [1.6.5] Application of the Civil Procedure Act in various courts

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.6.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 Pts 3–9, s 4.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 1.

heading.title: Application of the Civil Procedure Act in various courts

p.text: The CPA generally applies to all civil proceedings in the Supreme, District and Local Courts as well as to proceedings in the Dust Diseases Tribunal and the Land and Environment Court. However, CPA s 4 permits the UCPR to exclude particular classes of proceedings from the application of any provisions in CPA Pts 3–9 . The present rule effects those exclusions, by reference to Sch 1 . None of the exclusions affects proceedings in the Supreme Court or the District Court or the Land and Environment Court.

level.toc-caption: [1.6.10] Exclusions relating to the DDT

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.6.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 139, 153, ss 81, 84.

One exclusion in Column 3 of Sch 1, ss 81 – 84 of the CPA (interim payments) applies to proceedings in both the Dust Diseases Tribunal and in the Small Claims Division of the Local Court. Another exclusion, CPA ss 139 – 153 (transfer of proceedings) applies only to proceedings in the Dust Diseases Tribunal.

level.toc-caption: [1.6.15] Exclusions relating to the Local Court (Small Claims Division)

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.6.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 1.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 130, ss 25, 34, ss 35, 55, s 60, s 70, ss 81, 84, s 87, s 92, s 98.

heading.title: Exclusions relating to the Local Court (Small Claims Division)

p.text: Several of the exclusions provided for in Column 3 of Sch 1 apply only to proceedings in the Small Claims Division of the Local Court. The combined effect of the exclusions relating to the Local Court (Small Claims Division) can be summarised as excluding the following provisions of the CPA:
Pt 4 ( ss 25 – 34 ) Mediation
Pt 5 ( ss 35 – 55 ) Arbitration
s 60 Proportionality of costs
s 70 Informal proof and admissions
ss 81 – 84 Interim payments
s 87 Interlocutory protection against incrimination
s 92 Judgments for possession of land
s 98 Costs
s 130 Limitations on the enforcement of judgments

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.7] r 1.7 Local rules that prevail over these rules

leg:heading.title: Local rules that prevail over these rules

p.text: The rules of court specified in Schedule 2 prevail over these rules.

level.toc-caption: [1.7.5] Exception to the priority of the UCPR

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 11, s 11(1).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.7.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999.
(NSW) Land and Environment Court Rules 2007.

heading.title: Exception to the priority of the UCPR

p.text: CPA s 11 provides that, subject to any contrary provision they contain, the UCPR prevail over any inconsistent provisions of the former rules (ie, “local rules”) of each of the courts to which the CPA applies. The limited contrary provision contemplated by CPA s 11(1) is contained in r 1.7 . Under that rule, and UCPR Sch 2, a number of local rules prevail over the UCPR. These include all rules in the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 , the Land and Environment Court Rules 2007 and the Dust Disease Tribunal Rules.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.8] r 1.8 Determination of questions arising under these rules (cf SCR Part 23, rule 4(b) and (d))

leg:heading.title: Determination of questions arising under these rules (cf SCR Part 23, rule 4(b) and (d))

p.text: The court may determine any question arising under these rules (including any question of privilege) and, for that purpose:
may inspect any document in relation to which such a question arises, and
if the document is not before the court, may order that the document be produced to the court for inspection.

level.toc-caption: [1.8.5] Power to inspect to determine privilege claims

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 133, 183.

heading.title: Power to inspect to determine privilege claims

p.text: The court has power under ss 133 and 183 of the Evidence Act 1995 to inspect documents for the purpose of determining a contested privilege claim. Despite some controversy (as to which see Roscoe, Evidence in Civil Actions, 20th ed, Vol 1, pp 159–62; Glass et al, Seminars on Evidence, Law Book Co, 1970, p 8 (no power to inspect); Cox v Cox (1894) 10 WN (NSW) 158b ; Stewart v Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd (1894) 11 WN (NSW) 92 ; Lion Rolling Mills Pty Ltd v Noyes Bros (Melbourne) Pty Ltd [1915] VLR 383 at 387; (1915) 21 ALR 362 ); the balance of authority favours the existence of a similar common law power of inspection: Esso Australia Resources Ltd v FCT (1999) 201 CLR 49; 168 ALR 123 at 137; [1999] HCA 67; BC9908417 ; Grant v Downs (1976) 135 CLR 674 at 689; 11 ALR 577; BC7600095 per Stephen, Mason and Murphy JJ; Alister v R (1984) 154 CLR 404; 51 ALR 480; BC8500543 (power to inspect to determine a claim for public interest immunity); Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) v Bank of New Zealand (1991) 26 NSWLR 711 at 727; 6 ACSR 331 (power to inspect); see also National Australia Bank Ltd v Saunders (1988) 12 NSWLR 623; 13 ACLR 299 ; Young v Quinn (1985) 4 FCR 483; 59 ALR 225 ; New Cap Reinsurance Corporation Ltd (in liq) v Renaissance Reinsurance Ltd [2007] NSWSC 258; BC200701984 at [51] (inspection of draft expert’s report to determine whether service or use of the report would be inconsistent with maintaining confidentiality in the privileged materials).

level.toc-caption: [1.8.10] Exercise of the power to inspect to determine privilege claims

heading.title: Exercise of the power to inspect to determine privilege claims

p.text: Exercise of the power to inspect documents in order to determine a disputed privilege claim is a matter of discretion. In Grant v Downs (1976) 135 CLR 674 at 689; 11 ALR 577; BC7600095 Stephen, Mason and Murphy JJ opined that the inspection power had been exercised too sparingly in the past, possibly as a result of a misplaced reluctance to go behind a formal claim of privilege. The terms of the present rule are perhaps intended to endorse that view. Nevertheless, inspection remains a matter for discretionary decision. There are many instances where the character of the documents sufficiently indicates the purpose for which they have been brought into existence and where inspection is unnecessary. If a claim of privilege is formally made, the documents are clearly identified and the claim is apparently valid, the court is not obliged to inspect: Gazcorp Pty Ltd v Liverpool City Council [2006] NSWSC 490; BC200603705 at [19] (unnecessary for court to inspect documents); Ampolex Ltd v Perpetual Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (1995) 37 NSWLR 405 at 409; BC9505356 per Giles J (court was not invited to inspect the documents and did not do so). Furthermore in non-jury trials, unless the circumstances provide a substantial contrary justification, inspection may be undesirable: Westminster Airways Ltd v Kuwait Oil Co Ltd [1951] 1 KB 134 ; Grant v Downs (1976) 135 CLR 674 at 677; 11 ALR 577; BC7600095 per Barwick CJ; Weiier v Greening [1957] VR 296 at 299; ALR 594 . Sometimes the privilege claim may be able to be determined by inspection of uncontentious related documents or parts of documents: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2004] NSWSC 1089; BC200407581 . On other occasions it may be appropriate for the trial judge to refer the contested privilege claim for determination by another judge: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2004] NSWSC 1017; BC200407386 ; compare Re Southland Coal Pty Ltd (rec and mgrs apptd) (in liq) (2006) 203 FLR 1; 59 ACSR 87; [2006] NSWSC 899; BC200606961 (dispute between receivers and insurers, unlikely that proceedings to resolve the dispute would be heard in the same division, judge considered each document and ruled on privilege claim).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.9] r 1.9 Objections to production of documents and answering of questions founded on privilege (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13; DCR Part 28, rule 16)

leg:heading.title: Objections to production of documents and answering of questions founded on privilege (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13; DCR Part 28, rule 16)

p.text: This rule applies in the following circumstances:
if the court orders a person, by subpoena or otherwise, to produce a document to the court or to an authorised officer,
if a party requires another party, by notice under rule 34.1 , to produce a document to the court or to an authorised officer,
if a question is put to a person in the course of an examination before the court or an authorised officer,
[subr (1) am Amendment 24 of 2009, r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 6 March 2009]
In subrule (1), authorised officer means:
any officer of the court, or
any examiner, referee, arbitrator or other person who is authorised by law to receive evidence.
A person may object to producing a document on the ground that the document is a privileged document or to answering a question on the ground that the answer would disclose privileged information.
A person objecting under subrule (3) may not be compelled to produce the document, or to answer the question, unless and until the objection is overruled.
For the purpose of ruling on the objection:
evidence in relation to the claim of privilege may be received from any person, by affidavit or otherwise, and
cross-examination may be permitted on any affidavit used, and
in the case of an objection to the production of a document, the person objecting may be compelled to produce the document.

This rule does not affect any law that authorises or requires a person to withhold a document, or to refuse to answer a question, on the ground that producing the document, or answering the question, would be injurious to the public interest.
[r 1.9 subst Amendment 2 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[1], effective 15 August 2005]

level.toc-caption: [1.9.2] Privileged documents and information

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.9.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 117–126, ss 126B, 126H, s 128, s 129, s 130.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 ss 295–306, s 87.
Privileged documents are those that contain privileged information. Privileged information is defined in the in the UCPR Dictionary. It means:
information to which client legal privilege applies (under ss 117–126 of the Evidence Act 1995)
protected confidence information (under ss 126B , 126H of the Evidence Act 1995)
counseling communications relating to sexual assault (under s 126H of the Evidence Act 1995 and ss 295–306 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986)
information tending to incriminate, or expose to liability for a civil penalty (see s 128 of the Evidence Act 1995 and s 87 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005)
information relating to court or arbitral deliberations (under s 129 of the Evidence Act 1995)
secret or confidential information relating to matters of state (under s 130 of the Evidence Act 1995)
evidence of settlement negotiations
information whose disclosure is statutorily prohibited.

level.toc-caption: [1.9.3] Objections to production and inspection

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.9.3] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Pt 3.10, ss 126A–126F, ss 126J–126L, ss 129–131, s 131A.

A person can rely on any of the categories of privilege summarised in [1.9.2] as a ground of objection to a requirement for the production of documents or to answer questions: Westpac Banking Corp v 789TEN Pty Ltd (2005) 55 ACSR 519; [2005] NSWCA 321; BC200507412 at [7] .

After a person objects to production on any of the permissible grounds, the basic proposition is that the court must rule on the objection before production can be compelled. This basic position is qualified by the court’s power to order the person to produce the documents to the court, if it requires access to the contentious documents in order to determine a contested privilege claim: see UCPR rr 1.8(b) and 1.9(5)(c) .

The basic immunity from production conferred by UCPR r 1.9(4) means that unqualified orders for production should not be made ex parte if they are expressed to compel production of documents to which valid privilege claims may apply, and before those claims have been determined: see Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [130]–[133] ; Re Nielson and Moller Autoglass (NSW) Pty Ltd (2008) 222 FLR 21; [2008] NSWSC 1197; BC200810052 at [68]–[82] . On the other hand, the person faced with a production requirement that includes privileged information must assemble the relevant documents, put any grounds of objection to the court, and obtain the court’s ruling on the objection. The person should not anticipate the court’s ruling, by not including the privileged documents and information in the information they assemble in response to the production requirement: Re Triflex Electricl Pty Ltd (in liq) [2012] NSWSC 1206; BC201210584 at [16]–[18] ; Re Kala Capital Pty Ltd (No 2) [2012] NSWSC 1293; BC201210054 at [16]–[17] .

The present rule complements (although it differs in scope from) the analogous provision in s 131A of the Evidence Act 1995. Under that section a person may object to complying with interlocutory requirements for the production of documents, or the provision of information, if compliance would result in the disclosure of:
confidential professional confidences (under ss 126A–126F of the Evidence Act 1995)
the identity of a journalist’s confidential informer (under ss 126J–126L of the Evidence Act 1995)
information relating to court or arbitral deliberations, settlement negotiations or secret or confidential information relating to matters of state (under ss 129–131 of the Evidence Act 1995).

If the producing person’s privilege claim is upheld, no question about subsequent inspection of the documents will ordinarily arise. But inspection questions may arise where privilege is claimed by a party other than the person who produced the documents. In such a case UCPR r 1.9 does not explicitly apply to excuse either production or inspection (Carbotech-Australia Pty Ltd v Yates [2008] NSWSC 1151; BC200809838 at [6]–[13] per Brereton J) although the privileged status of the documents (for the purpose of Evidence Act 1995 Pt 3.10 ) would be relevant to the exercise of the discretion to permit inspection: Cassanti v Paragalli (2006) 229 ALR 416; [2006] NSWSC 160; BC200601413 at [18] and [26] .

The party claiming privilege bears the onus of establishing the basis of the claim. The party seeking disclosure, production or inspection of the document or information which is the subject of the claim does not bear any onus of excluding privilege: Mitsubishi Electric Australia Pty Ltd v Victorian WorkCover Authority (2002) 4 VR 332 at 337; [2002] VSCA 59; BC200202330 per Batt JA, cited with approval by Austin J in Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2004] NSWSC 1089; BC200407581 at [2] . The particular evidentiary requirements necessary to discharge a claimant’s onus of proof are discussed in [21.5.70] .

level.toc-caption: [1.9.10] Self-incrimination privilege

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.9.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 87.

An order for production to which this rule applies is also likely to fall within the expression “order for production” for the purpose of CPA s 87 . That section applies where a person subject to an order for production objects on the basis of the privilege against self-incrimination. The section permits the court to require production of the disputed document, but requires the court to give the person a certificate under s 87(8) precluding the subsequent use of the disclosed information against the person (except in proceedings relating to the falsity of the information): see the notes accompanying CPA s 87.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.10] r 1.10 Powers of the judicial registrar (DCR Part 43A, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Powers of the judicial registrar (DCR Part 43A, rule 1)

p.text: The powers of the Judicial Registrar of the District Court are dealt with in DCR Pt 43A r 1.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.10A] r 1.10A Powers of associate Judges of the Supreme Court (cf SCR Part 60, rule 1A)

leg:heading.title: Powers of associate Judges of the Supreme Court (cf SCR Part 60, rule 1A)

p.text: Subject to subrule (2), an associate Judge of the Supreme Court may exercise any of the powers of the Court under the Civil Procedure Act 2005 , or under rules of court, in relation to defamation proceedings.
An associate Judge may not exercise the power conferred by rule 29.15 or 29.16 in relation to any such proceedings.

Section 118 of the Supreme Court Act 1970 sets out the powers exercisable by an associate Judge. Those powers include powers conferred by rules of court. In addition to the power conferred by this rule, see rule 1A of Part 60 of the Supreme Court Rules 1970, together with Schedule D to those rules, for other powers of the Supreme Court that may be exercised by an associate Judge.
[r 1.10A insrt Amendment 5 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[1], effective 1 January 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.10B] r 1.10B When Part 11A concerning service under Hague Convention has effect

leg:heading.title: When Part 11A concerning service under Hague Convention has effect

p.text: The Provisions of Part 11A have effect on and from the day on which the Hague Convention enters into force for Australia.
[r 1.10B insrt Amendment 27 of 2009 Sch 1[1], effective 10 July 2009]
